bibl.title: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Philip Showalter Hench, May 14, 1956

div1.p: Tate feels awkward about the action being taken to prevent Lambert's bill from being approved.

div1.head: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Philip Showalter Hench, May 14, 1956
div1.opener:
12 A
1530 Tyler Street
Berkeley, California
May 14, 1956
Philip S. Hench, M.D.
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnisota
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
Since you notified me about the action taken by the Walter
Reed Memorial Association against the Lambert bill in the
Senate, it would be appreciated by me if you would advise
me of the results of that action.

You see, it puts me in an awkward position: I would like to
reply to Lambert's latest letter to me. After all the words
of good-will extended to him by others, I cannot be the one
to tell him that these were just words, and of the new phase
before the Senate Committee. Neither can I be so hypercritical
as to write him a normal letter of inquiry, knowing as much
as I do.

I am of the old school where courtesy required the prompt ac-
knowledgement of letters. How can I write him when I have not
heard if you have written him or not or what has happened to
his case?

I did expect that we would meet in S. F. as you wrote me that
we would, and I could have learned something from you then.
div1.closer:
Hoping for a prompt reply, with best wishes to you,
Sincerely, Tate Paul L. Tate
